referenced_message.content:
At the moment there is not really any documenation provided for it. Also we are going to revisit webhooks in the upcoming releases.

That being said you can setup a webhook receiver, by navigating to Integrations webhook. On the receiver side you will have to filter out the interesting events and decide what you want to do with them.

You can also setup a custom webhook. This allows you to attach a transformation so that you can modify the payload of the event according to your needs.

My deploy.yml file looked like this

<@1033714246774706206> Just a side note around Ansible EDA. We have used it on an internal demo which the code is not published yet. When creating the webhook I used the docker gateway but milage may vary:

```
    log.info("Create Webhook")
    webhook = await client.create(
        kind="CoreStandardWebhook",
        data={
            "name": "Ansible",
            "url": "http://172.17.0.1:5000",
            "shared_key": "1234",
            "validate_certificates": False,
        },
    )
    await webhook.save(allow_upsert=True)
```

My ansible EDA `rulebook.yml` file looked like the following

```
- name: Example
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: false
  sources:
    - name: webhook
      ansible.eda.webhook:
        host: 0.0.0.0
        port: 5000
  rules:
    - name: Infrahub
      condition: 
        all:
          # - event.payload.event_type == "CoreProposedChange.updated"
          - event.payload.data.state.value in ["merged", "merging"]
      action:
        run_playbook:
          name: deploy.yml
```

you can use `host-gateway` on linux instead
a workaround to have `host.docker.internal`work everywhere is to add an extra_hosts entry
e.g. with docker-compose:
```
extra_hosts:
      - "host.docker.internal:host-gateway"
```

this is described in the official documentation, here: https://docs.docker.com/reference/cli/docker/container/run/#add-host

referenced_message.content: yeah `host.docker.internal` does not work on Linux. This is a Docker Desktop thing on macos and windows

messages.content:
The shared key is used for webhook signature verification. 
A way to authenticate and verify the payload of the webhook.
You will see that there is header `webhook-signature` send by Infrahub that contains a base64 encoded hmac. 
The shared key is used to calculate the hmac.

The major difference between a Webhook and a Custom webhook is that you can use a Python Transformation with the custom webhook that allows you to enrich/change the data of the event before it is being send to the webhook receiver.

```bash

```

At the moment we should be sending a create/update/delete event whenever you make a change to an object.

Regarding merging. We only send an event for merge actions that happen through a proposed change.

An example of the event you are looking for is attached.

Notice the state value `merging` of this `CoreProposedChange.updated` event.
Unfortunately, at this stage, we don't send another event when the merged completed, but you can work around that by making performing a query for the `CoreProposedChange` object (using the id from the event) and checking that the state is now `merged`. For example, using the SDK:

```python
from infrahub_sdk import InfrahubClientSync
client = InfrahubClientSync()
pc = client.get("CoreProposedChange", ids=["1822c843-9e2e-87eb-35aa-c512e74f40d6"])
assert pc.state.value == "merged"
```
Hey Guys, can someone provide a little more details of the current state of Webhooks? and how i can get it to fire when i perform a merge?

That being said you can setup a webhook receiver, by navigating to Integrations webhook. On the receiver side you will have to filter out the interesting events and decide what you want to do with them.

You can also setup a custom webhook. This allows you to attach a transformation so that you can modify the payload of the event according to your needs.

Right now you can retrieve and push on the device using Nornir or Ansible. 

You can send a webhook to √† FastApi or tower to tell an artifact is generated , but you will have to ‚Äúfilter out‚Äù on the receiving side for now as we don‚Äôt yet have a filtering mechanism on the webhook sender/creation side (refactor incoming in very soon)

I was thinking webhook triggered on Merg to an external tool like tower or a fastAPI app to trigger a config change to devices which need a change. But from the documentation, Webhooks does not seem to have that feature yet. Also, is there any discussions on implementing a jobs/scripts like in Nautobot/Netbox?
